original_data.question: An 11-year-old boy was brought in by his mother with red tender bumps on his legs. The patient’s mother says that his symptoms started 3 days ago with a low-grade fever, malaise, and joint pain. He began to improve over the next 2 days, but this morning, when he woke up, she noticed multiple painful red bumps on his shins. Past medical history is significant for a recent severe sore throat and fever 1 week ago which resolved without treatment. The vital signs include: temperature 38.0°C (100.4°F), blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, pulse 85/min, and respiratory rate 15/min. Physical examination reveals multiple, firm and tender erythematous nodules with indistinct borders, averaging 4 cm in diameter. Lesions are localized to the anterior surface of the lower legs. No evidence of drainage, bleeding, abscess formation or ulceration. Which of the following is the next best diagnostic step in this patient?

model_response:
The clinical presentation is most consistent with Lyme disease. The next best diagnostic step is to perform a blood test to confirm the diagnosis. The most sensitive and specific test for Lyme disease is the ELISA for IgG antibodies to B. burgdorferi. The Western blot is performed to confirm a positive ELISA.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Female parents, human or animal.
The inferior part of the lower extremity between the KNEE and the ANKLE.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Female parents, human or animal.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.

A precancerous neoplastic process that affects the cervical squamous epithelium without evidence of invasion. It is usually associated with human papillomavirus infection. It is characterized by the presence of mild atypia in the superficial epithelial layer that may be associated with koilocytosis. Maturation is present in the upper two thirds of the epithelium. Mitotic figures are not numerous and are present in the basal third of the epithelium.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.
Pain in the joint.
Next to or adjoining.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
The time period between dawn and noon.
The front part of the leg from below the knee to the ankle.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Inflammation of the throat (PHARYNX).

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
Having a structure or consistency that strongly resists stress or pressure.
Applied to pain that is tender, i.e., elicited by touching the affected body part. []
The length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle or sphere and connecting two points on the circumference.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
Being confined or restricted to a particular location. [HPO:probinson]
Of or involving the front of a main body.
The extended two-dimensional outer boundary of a three-dimensional object.
The pouring forth of a fluid.
Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
A lesion on the surface of the skin or a mucous surface, produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
